academicRules 1.0.0
  • Reference

Tune multiple numeric rules to approach a desired pass rate

tune_rules.Rd

Performs a grid search over multiple rules, each of which may have a vector of candidate numeric values. For each combination, it applies the updated ruleset, computes the pass rate, and identifies which combination yields a pass rate closest to the user-specified target.

Usage

tune_rules(
  data,
  ruleset,
  candidates,
  target_rate,
  outcome_col_name = "TUNED_OUTCOME"
)

Arguments

data

A data frame or tibble that will be classified.

ruleset

An object of class "academic_ruleset".

candidates

A named list of vectors. Each name corresponds to a rule in ruleset, and the vector is the candidate values to try for rule$value. For example: list(min_total=20:30, max_fails=0:3).

  • Each rule must be of type "minimum" or "maximum" (i.e., numeric).

  • If you include a "logical" rule in candidates, that won't work unless it also has a numeric field, which is rare.

target_rate

A numeric between 0 and 1, the desired pass rate.

outcome_col_name

Name of the outcome column in the classified data. Defaults to "TUNED_OUTCOME".

Value

A list with components:

best_params

A named vector of the numeric values for each rule that yields a pass rate closest to target_rate.

best_rate

The pass rate at that combination.

results

A data frame with one row per combination, containing the pass rate and the parameter values.

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Suppose we have a rule 'min_total' (minimum) that must be >=24
# and a rule 'max_2s' (maximum) that must be <=2
my_rules <- define_rule_set(list(
  min_total = list(type="minimum", value=24, dimension="Total"),
  max_2s    = list(type="maximum", value=2, dimension="count_2")
))

# We'll try min_total in [20, 22, 24, 26, 28] and max_2s in [1,2,3]
# aiming for a pass rate near 0.70
multi_res <- tune_rules(
  data = dummy_ib_data,
  ruleset = my_rules,
  candidates = list(min_total = seq(20, 28, 2),
                    max_2s    = 1:3),
  target_rate = 0.70
)
multi_res$best_params
multi_res$best_rate
head(multi_res$results)
} # }
